support_summary: SVIP (Small VCP-interacting protein) contains a VIM and binds directly to VCP, acting as a negative regulator of ERAD by modulating the interaction between VCP and other ERAD components like Derlin1 and gp78.

functions.cellular_process: SVIP (Small VCP-Interacting Protein) is an ER-resident protein that acts as an endogenous inhibitor of ERAD. It contains a VCP-interacting motif (VIM) and directly binds to VCP. By binding to VCP, SVIP competes with other VCP-interacting proteins on the ER membrane, such as the E3 ligase AMFR/gp78. This competition uncouples VCP from the core ERAD machinery, preventing the extraction of ubiquitinated substrates from the ER and thereby inhibiting their degradation.
functions.effect_description: Negatively regulates ERAD by binding to VCP and preventing its functional association with the E3 ligase gp78 and other components of the retrotranslocation machinery.
biological_consequence: SVIP is expressed and localized to the ER membrane → SVIP binds to VCP via its VIM domain → This binding sequesters VCP away from the AMFR/gp78 E3 ligase complex → The extraction of ubiquitinated substrates from the ER is blocked → ERAD is inhibited, leading to the accumulation of misfolded proteins.
specific_effects: SVIP is an endogenous inhibitor of the ERAD pathway.
SVIP contains a VIM that directly binds to VCP.
SVIP negatively regulates ERAD by uncoupling VCP and Derlin1 from the E3 ligase gp78.

evidence.paper_title: Regulation of ER-associated degradation via p97/VCP-interacting motif
evidence.relevant_quote: Additionally, SVIP (small p97/VCP-interacting protein), which contains a VIM in its N-terminal region, negatively regulates ERAD by uncoupling p97/VCP and Derlin1 from gp78. Thus SVIP may protect cells from damage by extravagant ERAD.

evidence.paper_title: SVIP induces localization of p97/VCP to the plasma and lysosomal membranes and regulates autophagy
evidence.relevant_quote: The small p97/VCP-interacting protein (SVIP) functions as an inhibitor of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway.

mechanism: SVIP (Small VCP-Interacting Protein) is an ER-resident protein that acts as an endogenous inhibitor of ERAD. It contains a VCP-interacting motif (VIM) and directly binds to VCP. By binding to VCP, SVIP competes with other VCP-interacting proteins on the ER membrane, such as the E3 ligase AMFR/gp78. This competition uncouples VCP from the core ERAD machinery, preventing the extraction of ubiquitinated substrates from the ER and thereby inhibiting their degradation.
effect: Negatively regulates ERAD by binding to VCP and preventing its functional association with the E3 ligase gp78 and other components of the retrotranslocation machinery.
summary: VCP inhibits SVIP to modulate er-associated degradation (erad), ultimately affecting erad is inhibited, leading to the accumulation of misfolded proteins.

evidence.paper_title: Regulation of ER-associated degradation via p97/VCP-interacting motif
evidence.relevant_quote: Additionally, SVIP (small p97/VCP-interacting protein), which contains a VIM in its N-terminal region, negatively regulates ERAD by uncoupling p97/VCP and Derlin1 from gp78. Thus SVIP may protect cells from damage by extravagant ERAD.

evidence.paper_title: SVIP induces localization of p97/VCP to the plasma and lysosomal membranes and regulates autophagy
evidence.relevant_quote: The small p97/VCP-interacting protein (SVIP) functions as an inhibitor of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway.
